zero-sum game where one side only wins and the other side loses zero days on
one hand can be useful to those testing defenses or planning offensive operations they can also lead to

leads to the question of what one should do when they find a zero-day vulnerability should they retain or
disclose government's face a risk reward
trade-off in deciding whether to keep the vulnerabilities that they find a secret and this decision has
implications beyond national security it touches on the legal system company
liability and consumer protection it might seem counterintuitive to some
where it may seem obvious to some but the interests of National Intelligence are sometimes at odds with the public if
a government keeps a vulnerability that they find secret to use as a weapon
against an adversary then the software maker can't patch it and consumers and
companies might get hacked so it's a debate among policy makers should a
government keep the zero-days they find a secret so that their information security folks
can use them both for offensive or defensive purposes well this might leave
the public and businesses vulnerable or should a government disclose the zero
days that they find so that they can get patched businesses and consumers might be safer but then that government loses
a potential weapon so it's a dilemma for policy makers and there's just not much
hard evidence and hard metrics to help them answer the question retain or
disclose today I'm going to tell you how we're helping to answer a piece of that
question the retain versus disclose question is calculated the decision

process in other parts of the world not much is known about this process either
in terms of the US only recently on November 15th 2017 so just a few weeks
ago the US White House released or published their guidelines on the
vulnerabilities equity process that is the considerations they take into account when in possession of a zero-day
vulnerability to examine whether to retain knowledge of the vulnerability or whether to publicly disclose information
about the vulnerability this Charter
discusses how there are many equities to consider defensive intelligence law

there are many variables at play and there are lots of questions the decision makers need to ask when deciding whether
to retain or disclose these include things like getting information about
the product that the vulnerability is in so for example the relationship that the
vendor has with the government how widely the product is used and where it
is used what access is are required to exploit that particular vulnerability the likelihood of a vendor to release a
patch the likelihood of a public to apply the patch also is good to know
information about the threat actor that might take advantage of the vulnerability so for example the

knowledge about the vulnerability how severe is the vulnerability and other
information like will enough businesses and consumers install and apply the

vulnerabilities equities process so my research and this talk examines the

long life if it lived more than nine and a half years the average life expectancy
